instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL) and Fusarium solani (F.S.)?
Output: In the related study, visible spectrum and nir spectrum were used for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL) and Fusarium solani (F.S.).

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL) and Fusarium solani (F.S.)?
Output: Raw spectra, significant wavebands obtained with the RELIEF algorithm, and various statistical features extracted from raw spectra were used for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL) and Fusarium solani (F.S.).

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification accuracy for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL) and Fusarium solani (F.S.) and how far can this metric go?
Output: Classification accuracy was chosen as the metric to evaluate the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases caused by FORL and F.S. The classification accuracy achieved as early as 3 days after inoculation (DAI) was the maximum in this study.

instruction: What machine learning models were used to classify healthy and infected tomato plants based on their hyperspectral reflectance?
Output: The machine learning models used to classify healthy and infected tomato plants based on their hyperspectral reflectance were decision tree, cubic support vector machine, and k-nearest neighbor models.

instruction: Can the use of certain spectral bands effectively distinguish healthy and diseased tomato plants at different disease stages, as found in the related study investigating changes in hyperspectral reflectance?
Output: Yes, the related study found that certain spectral bands can effectively distinguish healthy and diseased tomato plants at different disease stages. The spectral bands 508, 711, 540, 717, 536, 644 nm were found to be the most effective in distinguishing Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. radicis lycopersici (FORL)-infected plants from healthy plants, while the spectral bands 705, 1883, 525, 518, 444, 522 nm were the most effective in distinguishing Fusarium solani (F.S.)-infected plants from healthy plants. These findings suggest that hyperspectral reflectance can be used as an alternative approach for the early identification and classification of crown root rot and vascular wilt diseases in tomato plants.
